docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the elements of a health care bill that the Senate and House will have to reconcile, one of the thorniest is the issue of the so-called employer mandate. To what degree will Congress require employers to provide health insurance for their employees?

headline.main: Employer Mandate Becomes Sticky Issue in Reconciling Bills

docs.abstract: The employer mandate is one of the thornier issues to be resolved in health care legislation. To what degree might Congress require employers to provide health insurance for their employees?
docs.snippet: The employer mandate is one of the thornier issues to be resolved in health care legislation. To what degree might Congress require employers to provide health insurance for their employees?

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Room for Debate published a discussion on "The 40-Something Dependent Child." Readers responded with their own thoughts on why it has been increasingly difficult for younger generations to support themselves without family help.

headline.main: Dependent Adults: Victims or Spoiled Brats?

docs.lead_paragraph: So what does the House health care bill really cost? Throughout Thursday, news accounts focused on $894 billion. That was the total cost given out by aides to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, before the official cost analysis was released by the Congressional Budget Office.
docs.abstract: Close look at Congressional Budget Office report suggests that House health care bill will cost $1.055 trillion over 10 years (S)

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN AND ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Can Congress force people to buy health insurance? The White House says yes.
docs.abstract: Robert Gibbs, White House press secretary, takes issue with people who contend that individual mandate in health care legislation is unconstitutional; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Can Congress force people to buy health insurance?      The White House says yes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uninsured children who wind up in the hospital are much more likely to die there than hospitalized children covered by private or government insurance plans, according to one of the first studies to assess the impact of insurance coverage on children receiving hospital care. Researchers at Johns Hopkins Children's Center analyzed data on more than 23 million children's hospitalizations in 37 states from 1988 to 2005, in which nearly 39,000 children died. Uninsured children had a 60 percent higher risk of death than insured children, the researchers found.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Johns Hopkins Children's Center say that uninsured children who wind up in hospital are much more likely to die there than hospitalized children covered by private or government insurance plans; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Uninsured children who wind up in the hospital are much more likely to die than children covered by either private or government insurance plans, according to one of the first studies to assess the impact of insurance coverage on hospitalized children.

headline.main: Hospitalized Children Without Insurance Are More Likely to Die, a Study Finds

docs.abstract: A new study documents higher death rates among hospitalized children who lack insurance. But why?
docs.snippet: A new study documents higher death rates among hospitalized children who lack insurance. But why?

docs.lead_paragraph: In yet another sign that the age of adulthood seems to be rising, a provision in the new health care legislation pending in Congress would require insurers to allow children to remain dependents on their parents' health insurance plans until at least age 26 or 27.
docs.abstract: The age of adulthood is rising above 18 for a number of financial transactions. Here's a look at some.
docs.snippet: The age of adulthood is rising above 18 for a number of financial transactions. Here's a look at some.
